questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a paranasal sinus?
questions.explanation:
308 
Sold by @itachibot Pyriform sinus (fossa) is a part of hypopharynx. It lies on either side of the larynx and extends 
from pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of oesophagus. Sinuses are air-containing cavities in certain bones of skull. It is divided into 2 groups. Anterior group includes • Maxillary • Frontal • Anterior ethmoidal sinuses. Posterior group includes • Posterior ethmoid • Sphenoid sinuses.

questions.question: Question 2: Which is the largest paranasal sinus?
questions.explanation: Maxillary sinus is the largest of paranasal sinuses and occupies the body of maxilla.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is also known as antrum of Highmore?
questions.explanation: Maxillary sinus is also known as antrum of Highmore.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements is correct about the maxillary sinus?

options.a: Pyramidal in shape with base towards lateral wall of nose and apex towards zygomatic arch
options.b: Pyramidal in shape with base towards zygomatic arch and apex towards lateral wall of nose.

questions.explanation:
309 
Sold by @itachibot Maxillary sinus is pyramidal in shape, with base towards lateral wall of nose and apex directed 
laterally into the zygomatic process of maxilla and sometimes in the zygomatic bone itself.

questions.question:
Question 5: A pathologist is examining the specimen of a maxillectomy. Which of the following 
epithelium do you expect to find lining the maxillary sinus?
questions.explanation:
Paranasal sinuses are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells which secrete mucus. 
They're lined by the mucous membrane, which is continuous with that of the nasal cavity through 
the ostia of sinuses.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is most superior in location?
questions.explanation:
Frontal sinus is the most superiorly located sinus. It is situated between the inner and outer tables of frontal bone, above and deep to the 
supraorbital margin.

questions.question:
Question 7: An anxious father brings his newborn baby to the pediatrician after dropping his baby when 
shifting from one arm to another. The pediatrician orders a CT head, which is normal. Which 
of the following structures would you not expect to find in the CT?
questions.explanation:
The frontal sinus is absent or rudimentary at birth. Radiologically, the frontal sinus is able to be 
identified at 6 years and reaches full size only after puberty. At birth, only the maxillary and ethmoidal sinuses are present and are large enough to be 
clinically significant. Sphenoid sinus, though may be present, is usually undeveloped and 
non-aerated. 310

questions.question: Question 8: Where does the posterior ethmoidal sinus open?
questions.explanation: The posterior ethmoidal sinus opens into the superior meatus.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is true about sphenoid sinus?

options.a: Present in greater wing of sphenoid
options.d: Lateral wall is related to the pituitary gland

questions.explanation: Sphenoid sinus opens into sphenoethmoidal recess.

questions.question:
Question 10: You are an ENT resident performing endoscopic biopsy from the sphenoid sinus in a COVID 
patient with suspected mucormycosis. Through which of the following areas will you access 
the sinus?
questions.explanation:
The sphenoid sinus is accessed through the sphenoethmoidal recess which is situated above the 
superior turbinate. The ostium of the sphenoid sinus can be located endoscopically 1cm above the upper margin of 
the posterior choana near the posterior border of the septum.

questions.question:
Question 11: Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to removal of which of the following 
ethmoidal cells?
questions.explanation:
Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The 
optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells. 311 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Haller cells are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary 
sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to 
maxillary sinusitis. Option B: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinates. Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process and forms 
the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal and anterior 
ethmoidal sinuses drain.

questions.question:
Question 12: While performing functional endoscopic sinus surgery, the surgeon points out the Haller cells 
and their clinical significance. Which of the following is correct about these cells? 307 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: They are related to the maxillary sinus
options.b: They are related to the optic nerve
options.c: They are related to the sphenoid sinus
options.d: They are related to the facial nerve

questions.explanation:
Haller cells (infraorbital ethmoidal air cells) are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated in the 
roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary 312 
Sold by @itachibot sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis. The star-marked area in the given CT scan shows the Haller cell

questions.question: Question 13: What is occipitomental view with open mouth also known as?

options.b: pH of nasal secretions is around 7.

questions.explanation:
Occipitomental view is called Water's view. Water's view with an open mouth is known as Pierre's 
view. Among the given options, Water's view is the best answer. In Water's view, the patient’s head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film 
while the X-rays are projected from backward. The mouth is usually kept open, which allows 
visualizing the sphenoid sinus. Structures seen in Water’s view are: • Maxillary sinuses (seen best) • Frontal sinuses • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth) • Zygoma • Zygomatic arch • Nasal bone • Frontal process of the maxilla • Superior orbital fissure • Infratemporal fossa Other options: Option B: Towne's view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull. Structures seen are 
the petrous part of the pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum, 
internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is taken 313 
Sold by @itachibot for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis. Option C: Law's view is a lateral oblique X-ray view of the mastoid. Structures seen are the 
external auditory canal, mastoid air cells, tegmen, lateral sinus plate, and temporomandibular 
joint. Option D: Stenver's view is an X-ray view of the skull where the long axis of the petrous bone is 
parallel to the film. Structures seen are the entire petrous pyramid, arcuate eminence, internal 
auditory meatus, labyrinth with its vestibule, cochlea, and mastoid antrum. 314 
Sold by @itachibot Physiology of Nose and Paranasal Sinuses
